Comment: Not sure about "significantly". Cost advantage will  diminish as LNG transportation infrastructure develops and export restrictions drop.

Question: New technology for fracking natural gas, by lowering energy costs in the United States, will make US industrial firms more cost competitive and thus significantly stimulate the growth of US merchandise exports. (The experts panel previously voted on this question on May 23, 2012. Comment: Natural gas prices are NOT determined in a world market.  Prices in the US will be cheaper than those in most nations for a long time.

Legislation introduced in Congress would require the Federal Reserve to "submit to the appropriate congressional committees…a Directive Policy Rule", which shall "describe the strategy or rule of the Federal Open Market Committee for the systematic quantitative adjustment of the Policy Instrument Target to respond to a change in the Intermediate Policy Inputs." Should the Fed deviate from the rule, the Fed Chair would have to "testify before the appropriate congressional committees as to why the [rule]…is not in compliance." Enacting this provision would improve monetary policy outcomes in the U.S.
Comment: Given the increasingly important and discretionary role the Fed plays, supervision is essential. Congress may not be the right body to do it

Employers that discriminate in hiring will be at a competitive disadvantage, if their customers do not care about their mix of employees, compared with firms that do not discriminate.
Comment: The only caveat is that if other employees have a taste for discrimination, they may take costly actions against the hiring of minorities.

Question: Employers that discriminate in hiring will be at a competitive disadvantage, if their customers do not care about their mix of employees, compared with firms that do not discriminate.
Employers that discriminate in hiring will be at a competitive disadvantage, if their customers do not care about their mix of employees, compared with firms that do not discriminate.

Question: Employers that discriminate in hiring will be at a competitive disadvantage, if their customers do not care about their mix of employees, compared with firms that do not discriminate.

This is hearsay because I don't "do" monetary policy. But everything I've read says that Ben was extraordinarily creative and effective.
He had to find creative ways to get around a number of institutional constraints to do the  needful and he did
The ultimate judgement will depend on the exit strategy and how easily the fed will return to a more rule-based policy.
I don't like the "informed postmortems" part.  There is little agreement in macro.
Strong action as a lender of last resort was essential. This is what central banks do. In this instance, innovation by the Fed was crucial.

Fed could have been even more aggressive.  Could have recognized problems in shadow banking system earlier.  But hindsight is 20/20.
Let's see how the unwinding works.  Also, some of the policies had bad income-distribution consequences and some were fiscal policies.
No Ben, no avoiding depression. Full stop.
The counterfactual state of the world with muted, Fed responses is an ugly one.
Generally true. Some doubts about whether it would have been possible to impose haircuts on debtholders rather than use public funds.
A policy where the Fed let financial institutions go bankrupt or helped home-owners directly might have been better, but we will never know

It is hard to have confidence on this opinion. It is difficult to predict how history will play out; this is not just "economic" predictions

Bernanke understood very well the policy errors of the Fed during the Great Depression and had the courage to avoid repeating them.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: the choice of the gift giver is a signal of intensity of search effiort

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Cash is more efficient in a narrow sense, but holiday gift exchanges are about interpersonal relationships.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Clearly true if one ignores the pleasure one may get in choosing or receiving specific gifts.  Only in some cases are these factors minimal.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Are you serious? Presents serve multiple interpersonal purposes. Revealed preference indicates that income transfer is not the primary one.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Depends on goal: may have goal (like create emotional connection through item - as if economists had emotions!) not achievable with cash.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Giving a present gives one an occssion to think about the recipient. The effort one puts into buying can be an important signal as well.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: it's the thought (identifying the right present) that matters! In addition money lacks the surprise element.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Of course does not consider receiver's joy of giving, etc:

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Gifts serve many functions such as signalling regard and demonstrating social ties with the recipient.  Cash transfers don't do this as well

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: I don't want to be a scrooge!

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: This is the sort of narrow view that rightly gives economics  bad name.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: A large benefit is the pleasure of choosing something special for the receiver. Maybe one's hand-knit socks are more fun to give than cash!

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: "It is the thought that counts" has more truth than some allow.  Gifts are more than things.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Implications of a specific gift (signal it sends, behavioral impact) may give additional utility to either the giver or receiver.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: The act of giving or receiving gifts can add value to the gifts.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Instead of proposing to your wife w/diamond ring, you offer a gift card of equal value. Efficient--if you don't count your hospital bills.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: generally agree but exposes neoclassical econ limitations bc it excludes utility from gift giver or recipient choosing/receiving a gift.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Giver informs receiver of novel experience. And (John Solow) giver can't enjoy directly, but only with participation of receiver (jewelry)-see background information here

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: An assistant might prefer cash. For a friend a present that shows that you have thought about what matters to them might mean much more.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Recipients often want to know that the giver spent time thinking about the gift and acquiring it. Giving cash is too easy in their eyes.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: In some cases, non-pecuniary values are important, but in general, the statement is true.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Motivation for the present has to be non-monetary -- but try giving your spouse cash!

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: I know the argument (see link), but a costly signal can be worthwhile.-see background information here

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Only an economist could think like this.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Disagree because the value is the thought behind selecting the present, not the cash involved. So true for thoughtless presents.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: The judgment would seem to depend on the giver's motivation.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Gift giving is a form of communication.  Comparing the gift to what the recepient would purchase with cash misses the esssence of gifts.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Generally, of course.  But shopping takes time, and some gifts you would never have shopped for turn out to satisfy unsuspected preferences.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Balderdash. This narrow notion of "efficiency" -- and what life is about -- gives economists a bad name.  Here's to the winter solstice.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Many reasons why gifts may be better than cash. Signaling thoughtfulness. Specialized knowledge of giver. Gifts from travels...

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: For many (most?) gifts, "efficiency" is not the point.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Is this a trivial price theory quiz or an interesting behavioral question.? To test price theory, try a cash gift next Valentine's day.

Question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.
Comment: Bah, humbug.  Such a claim takes an oversimplified model too seriously. Gifts can serve many purposes.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: Taxpayers subsidize too much non-meritorious activity through the tax writeoff. Tax liability should not fall 1-for-1 with charitable giving

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: The wording implies that distortion is bad, but the point of the charitable deduction is to encourage charity, ie to "distort" behavior.

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: This is true with no externalities; there are many externalities to charitable giving.

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: If minimizing distortion is your target, though seems like a very odd one.

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: Less distortion, yes, but that is an efficiency issue to be traded off against the distributional effects. I would keep the deduction.

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: Arguably charity involves an externality and so should be subsidized...the giver feels good (or wouldn't do it) and the recipient benefits.

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: If other distortions lead to underfunding organizations receiving charitable giving as a result of tax treatment then the answer may differ.

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: There is a free rider problem with regard to (good) charities.  Removing the deduction could be more distortionary.

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: Deductions/exemptions overall, yes. But charitable alone? Not clear.

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: this is only half of the equation. possible that charitable deduction is most efficient way to achieve other important social goals

Question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.
Comment: Some but hardly all charitable giving generates public goods and thus relieves distortions. We should keep the good deductions only.

Comment: The weight of the evidence is that a modest increase in the minimum will have a small negative effect on employment of low skill workers.
I'm not aware of any strong evidence demonstrating this result.
Even among hourly paid workers with less than a high school diploma, only about 11% earn the Fed min wage or less. -see background information here
Past minimum wage increases have not had large disemployment effects, but we are still suffering high unemploment so effects may be worse.
The "noticeably" made me pause.  A bit harder yes, but not sure how noticeably.
Some
The empirical evidence now pretty decisively shows no employment effect, even a few years later.  See Dube, Lester and Reich in the REStat
I'm aware that some fairly clean natural experiments have not found effects.
Unemployment among low-skilled workers is already high by historic standards, indicating that wages are already too high for market-clearing
For some it will definitely reduce opportunities, but in other places it will not even be binding  Net effect is hard to tell
-see background information here
There would surely be some effect, but "noticeably" seems a reach.
Yes, I know the Econ 101 answer but the evidence suggests the effect on employment is between small and 0,.
There is little evidence that small changes in minimum wage cause employment falls, but this is larger.
Expected earnings of low skill workers will rise because higher wages/hours will more than offset reduced employment.
Decades of research on the minimum wage in the U.S. find that the distortionary effects are quite small.
Important to compare to alternatives like EITC.
About half min wage workers are under 25.   About a quarter of min wage workers are working fewer than 35 hours per week.  -see background information here
Given that we have a minimum wage, indexing it would make a lot of sense.
The evidence is pretty clear that employment effects are small and benefits to workers are first order.
Depends what your social welfare function looks like
The benefits go to the somewhat more skilled at the expense of the lowest, which does not seem to be desirable policy.
Workers most likely to benefit are those with medium skills. Workers most likely to lose (be unemployed) are those with the lowest skills.
Total effects are hard to tell, plus there are other policies like the EITC that might be more effective.
I think the EITC is better (targeted, not as distortionary).-see background information here
Not the easiest call, but the minimum wage has been higher in real terms in the past, so this would not move us into uncharted waters.
All methods of helping the poor cause distortions.  This one not bad.
But there are better alternative policies, most obviously increasing the EITC.

The Brookings Institution recently described a US carbon tax of $20 per ton, increasing at 4% per year, which would raise an estimated $150 billion per year in federal revenues over the next decade.  Given the negative externalities created by carbon dioxide emissions, a federal carbon tax at this rate would involve fewer harmful net distortions to the US economy than a tax increase that generated the same revenue by raising marginal tax rates on labor income across the board.

Question: Consider one of two proposals for restraining future Medicare spending, each by the same amount: The method that President Obama enacted in the Affordable Care Act — reducing Medicare-related payments to private insurers and altering the payment system for doctors and hospitals — imposes risks on future Medicare patients because over time the supply of doctors, hospitals and insurers willing to offer them health services may decline in response to restrained payments.
Comment: There is fat and monopoly markups in the system to be cut. The problem with the ACA is the absence of across the board credible cost cutting

Claims by incumbent presidents and challengers about how many private-sector jobs can be created in a four-year period by sector-level or other targeted policies should be viewed as rough guesses, because overall macroeconomic conditions drive aggregate employment in ways that dominate any net effects of polices that focus on specific industries or households.

Claims by incumbent presidents and challengers about how many private-sector jobs can be created in a four-year period by sector-level or other targeted policies should be viewed as rough guesses, because overall macroeconomic conditions drive aggregate employment in ways that dominate any net effects of polices that focus on specific industries or households.

Claims by incumbent presidents and challengers about how many private-sector jobs can be created in a four-year period by sector-level or other targeted policies should be viewed as rough guesses, because overall macroeconomic conditions drive aggregate employment in ways that dominate any net effects of polices that focus on specific industries or households.
Comment: Broad macro conditions and macro policy matter most, but targetted policies have a role.

Comment: Yes, it clearly has the tools, but will it use them quickly and aggressively, especially given the short-run cost in jobs? We may find out.
There's no upper bound on the Fed's contractionary power--it can sell bonds and raise the interest rate on reserves, the latter sans limit.
Lots of ways to tighten and failure to do so would have to be an active choice.
e.g., the Fed phased out its liquidity lending facilities when the worst of the crisis passed.-see background information here
But recall that inflation is below Fed goal.
Again depends on what 'substantially' means. There is some (uncertain) point at which long-term inflation expectations lose their anchor.
The difference between can do it and will do it is a bit tricky when we are talking about the Fed

An important reason why private college and university tuition has risen faster than the CPI during the past few decades is because competition for faculty members — whose potential earnings in other sectors have steadily improved — has driven up their pay faster than their productivity.
Comment: This is not the only reason but one factor. Universities are also spending more on other inputs, including more on administration.

Question: An important reason why private college and university tuition has risen faster than the CPI during the past few decades is because competition for faculty members — whose potential earnings in other sectors have steadily improved — has driven up their pay faster than their productivity.

An important reason why private college and university tuition has risen faster than the CPI during the past few decades is because competition for faculty members — whose potential earnings in other sectors have steadily improved — has driven up their pay faster than their productivity.
Comment: Faculty salary growth relative to instructional productivity matters, but other factors have played a more important role in tuition trends.

Comment: Maybe top colleges set a price at whatever insurer (or government lender) will pay then charge a co-pay to extract remaining surplus...

If the fiscal changes that are planned under current US law take place next year — including Bush era tax cuts expiring, Medicare payment rates to doctors being cut, the AMT applying to many more taxpayers, and automatic cuts in defense and non-defense discretionary spending kicking in — then US real GDP growth in 2013 will be lower than it would be under the CBO's alternative fiscal scenario, in which the above changes do not occur.

If the fiscal changes that are planned under current US law take place next year — including Bush era tax cuts expiring, Medicare payment rates to doctors being cut, the AMT applying to many more taxpayers, and automatic cuts in defense and non-defense discretionary spending kicking in — then US real GDP growth in 2013 will be lower than it would be under the CBO's alternative fiscal scenario, in which the above changes do not occur.

If the fiscal changes that are planned under current US law take place next year — including Bush era tax cuts expiring, Medicare payment rates to doctors being cut, the AMT applying to many more taxpayers, and automatic cuts in defense and non-defense discretionary spending kicking in — then US real GDP growth in 2013 will be lower than it would be under the CBO's alternative fiscal scenario, in which the above changes do not occur.

If the fiscal changes that are planned under current US law take place next year — including Bush era tax cuts expiring, Medicare payment rates to doctors being cut, the AMT applying to many more taxpayers, and automatic cuts in defense and non-defense discretionary spending kicking in — then US real GDP growth in 2013 will be lower than it would be under the CBO's alternative fiscal scenario, in which the above changes do not occur.

If the fiscal changes that are planned under current US law take place next year — including Bush era tax cuts expiring, Medicare payment rates to doctors being cut, the AMT applying to many more taxpayers, and automatic cuts in defense and non-defense discretionary spending kicking in — then US real GDP growth in 2013 will be lower than it would be under the CBO's alternative fiscal scenario, in which the above changes do not occur.
Comment: Nevertheless, I'd rather go over the 'fiscal cliff' than renew our irresponsible and unsustainable spend-don't-tax policies.

If public school students had the option of taking the government money (local, state, federal) currently being spent on their own education and turning that money into vouchers that they could use towards covering the costs of any private school or public school of their choice (e.g. charter schools), most would be better off.
Comment: Too much uncertainty about equilibrium effects, though it is clear that public schools are failing and alternatives are necessary.

Question: If public school students had the option of taking the government money (local, state, federal) currently being spent on their own education and turning that money into vouchers that they could use towards covering the costs of any private school or public school of their choice (e.g. charter schools), most would be better off.

Because the U.S. Treasury bailed out and backstopped banks (by injecting equity into them in late 2008, and later committing to provide public capital to any banks that failed the stress tests and could not raise private capital), the U.S. unemployment rate was lower at the end of 2010 than it would have been without these measures.

Because the U.S. Treasury bailed out and backstopped banks (by injecting equity into them in late 2008, and later committing to provide public capital to any banks that failed the stress tests and could not raise private capital), the U.S. unemployment rate was lower at the end of 2010 than it would have been without these measures.

Because the U.S. Treasury bailed out and backstopped banks (by injecting equity into them in late 2008, and later committing to provide public capital to any banks that failed the stress tests and could not raise private capital), the U.S. unemployment rate was lower at the end of 2010 than it would have been without these measures.
Comment: If the banking system had collapsed, unemployment would certainly have been higher in 2010.

networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak

to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.

Italy as a problem likely to get worse before it gets better.

not good. not good.

Debt 120%, deficit 4%, growth 4% (nominal) --> ratio falling.  Higher rates (say pushing the deficit on a path toward 8%) --> ratio rising.-see background information here-see background information here-see background information here-see background information here-see background information here

italy needs deep domestic refroms and a solution of the eurpoean French-German impasse on the role of the ECB

without growth, all the austerity you can muster will not solve the problem

Question:
Eliminating tax
deductions for non-investment personal interest expenses (e.g., on mortgages),
with reductions in personal tax rates that are both budget neutral and keep the
burden of taxes by income group the same, would lead to more efficient
financing decisions by individuals.
Comment: There is no reasonable Pigovian justification for mortgage deductions, which are not only distortionary but also generally regressive.

Comment: That is my understanding, but this is second-hand information, not my area of expertise.

Yes, but the situation is not as extreme as was the case a few years ago.
Everyone thinks so.  Can everyone be wrong?  Yes.  But not every time, and not most of the time.
Seems uncontroversial.
The undervaluation of the currency is part of their growth strategy.  Higher prices for consumers; more demand for products from abroad.
multiple trillions of foreign reserves, giant trade surpluses, fighting to contain domestic inflation.  Smells a whole like undervaluation.
China has many policies; some raise and some lower the value of the yuan. Absent the ones that lower its value, it would rise.
The same policies are creating big imbalances in China by thwarting price signals. The eventual adjustment for China could be ugly.   -see background information here
They use the exchange rate for monetary policy, but some knowledgeable economist believe that the rate would be higher with float.
Would expect that China amassing $3 trillion in dollar reserves has an effect on the exchange rate.
This has been acknowledged, at least privately, by Chinese officials themselves.
I don't know enough about what China may or may not be doing to state an informed opinion.
Although these policies also increase inflation, what erodes a portion of the impact on the real exchange rate.
Not my terrain.  I know little more than what I read in the unreliable press.
Not my area.
Vouchers likely to improve things in short run given the awful state of US public schools. But we know little about their long run effects.
The evidence is mixed on the benefits of school choice.
Maddeningly sweeping! Some students would benefit and the average effect might indeed be positive. But some students would surely be harmed.
Those using vouchers would likely be better off, but others might be worse - need to consider system-level and distributional effects.
The kids whose parents don't pay attention or are poorly informed can be worse off.  Otherwise agree.
More motivated and able students would take advantage of the vouchers, but the students left behind would likely be worse off.
The existing alternatives to public schools are not all of uniformly higher quality; adverse selection is a big deal too.
And what about the kids that don't take up the vouchers?
Maybe yes. And maybe those left behind would do worse. The equilibrium could be tough.
On the plus side, incentives are better under vouchers.  On the negative side, decision making might be in the hands of those with less info
I think the majority of public school students would be better off, but certainly not all.  The question is ambiguous about the percent.
Treating students as clients does not improve education. Evidence on voucher programs very mixed - no robust evidence of positive effects.
Many public school students would benefit but some with little choice might not.  On net it would be beneficial and increase competition.
Competition is likely beneficial on average. Less clear that all students would benefit leading to tough ?s about social welfare functions
The problem with cashing out public support of education is that parents are the agents of children and some parents are poor agents.
There is enough in avg student's per-pupil budget for a solid supply-side response-i.e. what's needed for widespread benefits of competition
I do not believe that all students would be better off.
Hard to know what the equilibrium will be, but so many kids are trapped now eventually most of them would have better choices.
If peer effects are important, could have most gain but some lose.-see background information here
The main disadvantage to vouchers is potential weakening of public schools.  But those that would lose students are terrible already.
Hard to give a blanket answer to this question
This is a complicated question with arguments on both sides.
Hard to predict what a privatized school system would look like.
The issues and caveats strike me as far too complex for 140 characters.
Many would of course benefit, but those in rural areas or with irresponsible parents wouldn't.  Charters aren't magic.
School choice has merits but the system is complex and long-term effects on both private and public education is unclear.
It's the only way to break the unions.  Why do that?  Fran Tarkenton said it all in his recent WSJ op ed piece.-see background information here
Hurray for charter schools but to go to full vouchers it is necessary to deal with possible unraveling if no schools want the bottom kids.

Question: All else equal, permanently raising the federal marginal tax rate on ordinary income by 1 percentage point for those in the top (i.e., currently 35%) tax bracket would increase federal tax revenue over the next 10 years.
Comment: Disincentive effects on labor supply and entrepreneurship, and tax avoidance are likely, but not large enough to reduce revenues.

All else equal, permanently raising the federal marginal tax rate on ordinary income by 1 percentage point for those in the top (i.e., currently 35%) tax bracket would increase federal tax revenue over the next 10 years.
